entry.summary:
SVRPHI
The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Northwestern Warren County in northwestern New Jersey... Northeastern Monroe County in northeastern Pennsylvania...
* Until 445 PM EDT.
* At 404 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over East Stroudsburg, or 12 miles southeast of Mount Pocono, moving northeast at 20 mph.

IMPACT...Minor damage to vehicles is possible. Wind damage to roofs, siding, trees, and power lines is possible.

This includes the following highways... Interstate 80 in Pennsylvania between mile markers 309 and 314. Interstate 80 in New Jersey between mile markers 0 and 2.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 18 at 4:02PM EDT until August 18 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM EDT THIS EVENING FOR CENTRAL FAIRFIELD AND NORTHWESTERN NEW HAVEN COUNTIES...
At 402 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain in Central Fairfield to Northern New Haven Counties. Widespread water rescues are taking place, especially in the Southbury area. Several mudslides have also been reported. Between 5 and 9 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 0.75 to 1.5 inches in 1 hour. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring.
This is a FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY for Central Fairfield County toward Northern New Haven Counties. This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW!
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW! Life threatening flash flooding of low water crossings, small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Waterbury, Danbury, Shelton, Naugatuck, Southbury, Newtown, Fairfield, Trumbull, Ridgefield, Monroe, Bethel, Wilton, Brookfield, Weston, Redding, Middlebury, Beacon Falls, Georgetown, Oxford and Easton.
Law enforcement is reporting widespread water rescues taking place from Central Fairfield County into Northern New Haven County. In addition to reports of several mudslides, some road washouts have also been reported, particularly around the Southbury area.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fairfield, CT; New Haven, CT

cap:parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY FOR CENTRAL FAIRFIELD COUNTY TOWARD NORTHERN NEW HAVEN COUNTIES

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued August 18 at 11:56AM AKDT until August 18 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* LOCATION...Along the Kuskokwim Delta coast, especially the communities of Kongiganak, Kwigillingok, and Kipnuk.
* COASTAL FLOODING...Water levels will rise as high as 3 to 6 feet above normal highest tide. While water levels will drop during low tide, expect higher than usual water levels to return during high tide.
* TIMING...Through 6 PM Sunday, as a final round of strong winds impact the Kuskokwim Delta coast. The timing of highest water levels will depend on tide cycles at your location. The strongest winds are expected through this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding of low lying areas along the coast. Strong winds, high surf, and wave run-up could move property along the shoreline. Coastal erosion is possible. Strong, sustained winds could slow the retreat of water during low tide.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There is now increased confidence for the most significant higher water, waves and strong winds to occur around midday today. Winds and higher than normal water levels will slowly diminish by Sunday night.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kuskokwim Delta

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 18 at 3:44PM EDT until August 19 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible with more showers and thunderstorms on the way for tonight.
* WHERE...Portions of southern Connecticut, including the following areas, Northern Fairfield, Northern New Haven, Southern Fairfield and Southern New Haven and southeast New York, including the following areas, Northern Westchester, Putnam and Southern Westchester.
* WHEN...Until 2 AM EDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - More moderate to heavy rain showers through much of tonight have the potential to produce flash flooding, along with urban and poor drainage flooding. Rainfall rates of near 1 to 3 inch per hour can be expected. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Fairfield; Northern New Haven; Southern Fairfield; Southern New Haven; Putnam; Northern Westchester; Southern Westchester

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 18 at 11:41AM AKDT until August 19 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Winds from a coastal storm will cause water to backup on the Kuskokwim River and surrounding low lying areas.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by high winds backing up flow along the lower Kuskokwim River and Kuskokwim Delta is expected.
* WHERE...Along the Kuskokwim River, related tributaries and low lying areas including: Akiak, Bethel and several other smaller communities downstream to the Delta.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Residents reported flooding and rapid bank erosion during Friday and Saturday's high tide at Akiak, Napakiak, Kasigluk, and Tuntutuliak. At Napakiak, residents reported high water threatening community infrastructures, from Friday and Saturday's high tide, inundating most low spots in the village, including the the road to the dump. Water levels are reported to be higher than during breakup flooding this past May. Residents in Kasigluk reported water was encroaching on low lying residences, with water levels similar to those seen during this year's breakup. In Tuntutuliak, residents are reporting high water in the village over the past few days.
Based on tidal and storm surge forecasts, river levels are expected to be highest during Sunday's high tide, with water levels at Bethel, along Brown's Slough, approaching the flood stage of 8.5 feet by Sunday afternoon.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1112 AM AKDT, a strong storm system has tracked northward across the Bering Sea towards Norton Sound, just to the north of the Y-K Delta as of late Sunday morning. Strong southwesterly winds, and associated storm surge, continue to block flow along the Kuskokwim River. High tide on Sunday will correspond closely to very high water levels along the lower Kuskokwim, causing inundation of homes and infrastructure, along with rapid bank erosion.
- For Kuskokwim River at Bethel: At 11:00am the stage was 5.07 feet at low tide. Flood Stage is 8.5 feet.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kuskokwim Delta

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKDT MONDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 18 at 11:41AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A series of low pressure systems will impact the West Coast with strong winds, rain, and potential coastal flooding.
The first and weakest of these Bering storms is moving through the Bering Strait today into tonight, bringing large breaking waves and elevated water levels along the West Coast through Monday afternoon. Conditions are expected to improve Monday afternoon. For the latest details on this storm, please see current High Surf Advisories.
The second and stronger low, the remnants of Typhoon Ampil, will move north and east out of the northern Pacific into the southern Bering Sea Monday into Tuesday, into the central Bering Sea Tuesday night, and through the Bering Strait Wednesday. This track will bring a long fetch of strong and gusty southwesterly winds to areas south of the Bering Strait Tuesday into Wednesday. This dynamic fetch will enhance the potential of coastal flooding along the West Coast south of the Bering Strait Wednesday into Thursday. Weather models vary on timing and exact track of this storm at this time. The track of this low will greatly affect which areas see the strongest winds and highest water levels. We will continue to closely monitor this storm.
Stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 18 at 3:32PM EDT until August 18 at 5:30PM EDT by NWS Binghamton NY
entry.summary:
At 332 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated another round of thunderstorms producing heavy rain moving into the warned area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain has already fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Carbondale, Archbald, Forest City, Mayfield, Waymart, Union Dale, Starrucca, Pleasant Mount, Shehawken, Starruca, Starlight, Hiawatha, Tompkinsville, Equinunk, Sherman, Mount Cobb, Blakely, Jessup, Clifford and Jermyn.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 18 at 3:21PM EDT until August 20 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall last week and elevated tides.
* WHERE...A portion of northeast South Carolina, including the following county, Horry.
* WHEN...Until 1100 AM EDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...At 17 feet...flooding of about three dozen ground level structures on Rosewood Drive, Star Creek Circle, and Recreation Road worsens and about 24 more ground level structures begin to flood. Flooding expands on Rosewood Drive, River Road, Ed Smith Avenue, Creekside Drive, Mill Creek Road, Smith Boulevard, Folly Lane, John Henry Lane, Star Creek Circle, West Oak Circle and Roberta Lane with residences isolated. Zeddie Lane, Renata Lane, and Earls Road begin to flood. Lowest yards along Shem Creek Circle begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 305 PM EDT, Heavy rainfall from last week, and elevated tides will continue to create issues along the Waterway near Socastee.
The Waterway at Socastee is forecast to peak to 16.5 to 16.7 feet tonight into Monday. The water levels are not expected to fall below 15 ft until late next weekend. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Socastee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Socastee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Horry, SC

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 18 at 2:54PM EDT until August 18 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall.
* WHERE...Portions of DC, including the following , District of Columbia, Maryland, including the following areas, Anne Arundel, Carroll, Cecil, Central and Southeast Howard, Central and Southeast Montgomery, Northern Baltimore, Northwest Harford, Northwest Howard, Northwest Montgomery, Prince Georges, Southeast Harford and Southern Baltimore, and northern Virginia, including the following areas, Arlington/Falls Church/Alexandria, Eastern Loudoun and Fairfax.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Widespread showers and thunderstorms are expected this afternoon into this evening with multiple rounds possible. Thunderstorms may be capable of producing intense rainfall rates of one to two inches per hour with locally higher amounts up to three inches. This may result in flash flooding of small streams and creeks as well as urban and poor drainage areas. - Please visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for flood safety and preparedness information

entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Inland Brunswick County.
* WHEN...From 7 PM this evening to midnight EDT tonight.
* IMPACTS...Portions of Battleship Road and USS North Carolina Road may become impassable. In downtown Wilmington, flooding expands on Water Street from Orange Street to Red Cross Street. entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 18 at 2:26PM EDT until August 18 at 5:30PM EDT by NWS Binghamton NY
entry.summary:
FFWBGM
The National Weather Service in Binghamton has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... North Central Chenango County in central New York... Southeastern Madison County in central New York... Southeastern Oneida County in central New York...
* Until 530 PM EDT.
* At 226 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Utica, Rome, Hamilton, New Hartford, New York Mills, Yorkville, Clinton, Plymouth, North Norwich, Waterville, Oriskany, Sherburne, Earlville, Clayville, Madison, Smyrna, Solsville, Poolville, Clark Mills and Kirkland.

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Missouri...
Gasconade River at Jerome affecting Phelps County.
For the Gasconade River...including Jerome...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Gasconade River at Jerome.
* WHEN...From this evening to early Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, minor flooding occurs near the gage site. Flood waters reach the lower edge of the concrete building where the gage equipment is located.

It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.3 feet on 07/04/2015. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 18 at 1:45PM EDT until August 19 at 1:30PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continues to report gradually rising water levels in southeastern Madison County between State Road 53 and the Suwannee River. Water levels remain high in the vicinity of I-10 and Exit 258 and 262. All of the flooding is due to past heavy rainfall from Hurricane Debby. Expect new flooded areas as water continues to slowly move to the south and east across Madison County.
* WHERE...A portion of Big Bend Florida, including the following county, Madison.
* WHEN...Until 130 PM EDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 139 PM EDT, Madison County Emergency Management reports continued flooding in the warned area. - Flooding will likely persist into next week due to more than 12 inches of rain that occurred across the warning area from Hurricane Debby around August 5. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Lee and Hopewell. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Madison, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 130 PM EDT MONDAY

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued August 18 at 3:10AM HST until August 19 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...MINOR COASTAL FLOODING DURING AFTERNOON HIGH TIDES THROUGH MONDAY...
.Higher-than-predicted water levels combined with near-peak monthly tides will lead to minor coastal flooding each afternoon through Monday. A south swell arriving tonight and peaking late Monday will increase the flooding potential along south facing shores Monday afternoon. Water levels will gradually lower Tuesday through the rest of the week.
* WHAT...Isolated minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...Along shorelines and low-lying coastal areas of all islands.
* WHEN...Each afternoon through Monday during the peak daily high tide cycles.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of beaches that are normally dry, minor coastal erosion, and saltwater inundation.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 18 at 3:04AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
The combination of hot temperatures and elevated relative humidity values will result in moderate to major heat risk across Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley today. Heat index values are expected to range between 105 and 112 degrees this afternoon into early evening. Isolated areas may experience heat indices between 111 and 112 degrees for a short period of time.
If working outside today, be sure to drink plenty of water, wear loose-fitting and light-colored clothing, and take frequent breaks in air-conditioned locations. Be sure to check on elderly and infirm neighbors and relatives, provide shade and fresh water for outdoor pets and livestock, and check the backseat of your vehicle when transporting children.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Brooks; Inland Kenedy; Starr; Southern Hidalgo; Inland Willacy; Inland Cameron; Coastal Kenedy; Northern Hidalgo; Coastal Willacy; Coastal Cameron

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 17 at 3:30PM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Orange or Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category.
* WHERE...North central and northeastern Minnesota.
* WHEN...Until noon CDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota Friday evening.. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the northern half of Minnesota through Monday morning. Smoke will produce air quality in Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category intermittently from Friday evening through noon on Monday. The air quality may temporarily improve during the afternoon hours before degrading again overnight. Areas near Lake Superior may also experience smoke trapped in marine fog, similar to what occured earlier this week. Because of this air quality may be worse immediately surrounding Lake Superior compared to areas inland.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Koochiching; North St. Louis; Northern Cook/Northern Lake; North Itasca; Central St. Louis; Southern Lake/North Shore; Southern Cook/North Shore; North Cass; South Itasca; Northern Aitkin; Carlton/South St. Louis

AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Sunday, August 18, 2024
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Sunday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 4:08PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Orange or Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category.
* WHERE...North central and northwestern Minnesota.
* WHEN...Until noon CDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota Friday evening. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the northern half of Minnesota through Monday morning. Smoke will produce air quality in Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category intermittently from Friday evening through noon on Monday.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 12:16PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...in effect until noon PDT Monday.
This air quality advisory covers Lake and northern Klamath counties due to wildfires burning in the region. The DEQ also expects intermittent smoke in eastern Douglas and Jackson County through this period due to smoke from surrounding fires.
The wildfire smoke combined with forecast conditions will cause air quality levels to fluctuate and could be at unhealthy levels.
Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on the weather and planned burn operations. Smoke can irritate the eyes and lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk include infants and young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults and pregnant people.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: Klamath, OR; Lake, OR

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PDT MONDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 10:53AM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM PDT MONDAY.
A Smoke Air Quality Advisory has been issued. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes...runny nose...aggravate heart and lung diseases...and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
For additional information...please visit the Web site at http://www.oregon.gov/DEQ
entry.cap:areaDesc: Deschutes, OR

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 15 at 3:08PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Red or Unhealthy category.
* WHERE...Northwest Minnesota.
* WHEN...From 3 PM CDT Friday to 6 PM CDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Some members of the general public may experience health effects. Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota on Friday afternoon. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the Red River valley. Smoke will reach the border around 3 pm and arrive at the Fargo/Moorhead area around 6 pm Friday. Northerly winds will persist for several days and additional smoke is expected to move into northern Minnesota Saturday afternoon. The alert area may need to be expanded to account for additional areas that might be impacted by heavy smoke. Smoke will initially produce air quality in the Red (Unhealthy) AQI category Friday afternoon but levels may improve to the Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category on Saturday. Smoke will linger until at least Sunday, as light northerly winds are expected to continue until Monday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Polk; Norman; Clay; Kittson; West Marshall; Wilkin
